applications and software more accessible to the customers that we want
to enable to use it if you remember the early days of computing there wasn't
really a user interface access to the machine was controlled by a group of
wizards these will be your mainframe or systems operators you would be the write out your code literally write out your
code longhand and have them implement it into the machine for you or maybe you'd be lucky
enough to have a box of punch cards that you would punch bring along hand over to the operators and receive some punch
cards back or some printed paper back which had the results of your job either stamped in it or printed on it this is
generation 1 we then moved on to computer interfaces which use analogs
they use folders and files and radio buttons and buttons and sliders and a
mouse and pointer of course and this enables us to in turn enable a less sophisticated class of users to interact
with applications and use information systems there's a whole field here called skeuomorphism which is about
taking everyday objects and transporting them into the digital world so the
applications are immediately familiar to those people that you want to enable to them to use to use them the best example
would be like iPad applications for note-taking that have fake spiral binders down the side of them and stuff
like that it's about engendering familiarity with the application but we still need to know how to use the system
at its core right and now we're on the third generation which is I just type or

way which is conversational hence the name conversational interfaces they're
